title: Domino's Pizza eyes growth from 'fortressing' established markets
text:
"The total fast food [market] is only growing 1 per cent in our markets and in Japan total fast food is shrinking in line with the shrinking population, but digital delivery is growing at extraordinary rates," he said.

"Last year we grew 18 per cent online while our total sales grew 12 per cent, so all our growth came from online growth," he said.

Domino's sells online through its own platform and uses Uber Eats and Deliveroo in Australia, but pizzas ordered through aggregators are delivered by Domino's staff, who receive hourly wages and superannuation and are covered by insurance.

"Whether we get a customer from an aggregator or Google or Facebook or TV or leaflets they're all profitable for us and wherever the customer is we just want to be there and make sure it's our execution," Mr Meij said.

"We do see it as a differentiator ... customers know its Domino's delivering and that means a lot," he said.

Domino's issued no trading update and made no changes to long-term forecasts but indicated it would issue a detailed regional update at the annual meeting on October 28.

Domino's shares slipped 0.7 per cent to $47.66 but have risen 17 per cent since the full-year results in August, even though it missed earnings guidance for the third consecutive year, largely because of weaker profits in Australia and New Zealand.

"The country heads focused on the economics of store splits and aggregator impacts across regions but the market remains split on the outlook for both," said DNR Capital investment analyst Chris Tynan.

Advertisement

"A key point the market will be looking for is an acceleration in the European store roll out, particularly France. The opportunity in Europe remains significant but execution to date has lagged expectations," Mr Tynan said.

Domino's plans to more than double its store network in Europe from 1097 to 2850 by 2025-2030, but indicated there was scope for more than 5000 stores if Domino's had the same market penetration across Europe as it has in Australia (one store for every 35,000 customers) and Iceland (one for every 11,806).

"History shows we have nearly always upgraded [store targets] in the past," Mr Meij said.

In Australia and New Zealand, Domino's plans to increase stores from 825 to 1200 by 2025-2030 and Mr Meij believes there is scope to take sales from other fast food categories.

"The French eat three times more pizza than Australians and Germans eat three times more pizza than Australians, so Domino's sees opportunities to grow the pizza share of the market," he said.
description: Domino's Pizza says it can continue to grow by 'fortressing' its stores and working with, rather than against, online food aggregators.
